captions.text:
Derby Day on Wednesday June the fourth, 1913.
And as the highest and the lowest in the land

converged on Epsom Downs, this year there
was a particular buzz in the air, not to mention

a great deal of extra security, because the
King, George the Fifth, had a fancied runner

- a horse called Anmer, which was a strong
ante-post favourite.

Bt as the Royal party arrived to see the race,
there was another, more desperate sub-plot

running through the meeting, known to just
a handful of people. A demonstration was going

to be made on behalf of the suffragette movement.
This was an increasingly violent campaign

by women demanding the right to vote in political
elections. Hunger strikes, bomb attacks, marches

and meetings, had all been used in the years
beforehand to press the women's claims. But

what was to happen today, was to place the
suffragette cause onto quite another level

of public consciousness.
Just as the field was rounding Tattenham Corner,

a young woman stepped out from behind the
rails, waited for Anmer to come by, and as

it did, to the horror of the crowd, she grabbed
at the horse's reins, bringing it down. Emily

Davison was the young woman's name. She was
critically injured.

Slowed down, it's plain to see just how coolly
Miss regaining consciousness. Horse and jockey

both recovered.
Miss Davison's funeral brought thousands of

suffragettes and their supporters onto the
streets. There were wreaths from all over

the world. A guard of honour was provided
by women wearing white dresses and black sashes,

the symbol of the woman's suffragette movement.
Women got the vote five years later. That

they did so, was in no small measure due to
Emily Davison's brave sacrifice on Derby Day,

title: Emily Davison Throws Herself Under The Kings Horse (1913)

teacher told me she didn't plan to kill herself she was going else where

something good which turned into a tragedy. :(﻿

that your thinking process is reductive, reactionary, and dogmatic, similar 
to some sexist guys I've been around. So you're fighting stupid with 
stupid. Meanwhile, there are tons and tons of men out here who do our best 
to be supportive and understanding toward the women in our lives and our 
world, despite the constant mixed messages we receive about how we're 
supposed to act and feel toward women. We try to do the best we can to not

the fact that a large percentage of men today share this general attitude 
instead of trading in cynical male stereotypes.

comments.author: Blah b

comments.text:
+Blah b 
To Pierre Berton's question on January 19, 1965–"But you no longer believe 
in a black state?"–he gave the flat answer:
"No, I believe in a society in which people can live like human beings on 
the basis of equality."



In a conversation with Gordon Parks:
"Listening to leaders like Nasser, Ben Bella, and Nkrumahawakened me to the 
dangers of racism. I realized racism isn't just a black and white problem. 
It's brought bloodbaths to about every nation on earth at one time or 
another.
Brother, remember the time that white college girl came into the 
restaurant—​the one who wanted to help the [Black] Muslims and the whites 
get together—​and I told her there wasn't a ghost of a chance andshe went 
away crying? Well, I've lived to regret that incident. In manyparts of the 
African continent I saw white students helping black people. Something like 
this kills a lot of argument. I did many things as a [Black] Muslim that 
I'm sorry for now. I was a zombie then—​like all [Black] Muslims—​I was 
hypnotized, pointed in a certain direction and told to march. Well, I guess 
a man's entitled to make a fool of himself if he's ready to pay the cost. 
It cost me 12 years.

That was a bad scene, brother. The sickness and madness of those days—​I'm 
glad to be free of them."




Young Socialist: How do you define Black nationalism, with which you have 
been identified?

Malcolm X: I used to define Black nationalism as the idea that the Black 
man should control the economy of his community, the politics of his 
community, and so forth.

But when I was in Africa in May, in Ghana, I was speaking with the Algerian 
ambassador who is extremely militant and is a revolutionary in the true 
sense of the word (and has his credentials as such for having carried on a 
successful revolution against oppression in his country). When I told him 
that my political, social, and economic philosophy was Black nationalism, 
he asked me very frankly: Well, where did that leave 
him? Because he was white. He was an African, but he was Algerian, and to 
all appearances, he was a white man. And he said if I define my objective 
as the victory of Black nationalism, where does that leave him? Where does 
that leave revolutionaries in Morocco, Egypt, Iraq, Mauritania? So he 
showed me where I was alienating people who were true 
revolutionaries dedicated to overturning the system of exploitation that 
exists on this earth by any means necessary.

So I had to do a lot of thinking and reappraising of my definition of Black 
nationalism. Can we sum up the solution to the problems 
confronting our people as Black nationalism? And if you notice, I 
haven’t been using the expression for several months. But I still would be 
hard pressed to give a specific definition of the overall philosophy which 
I think is necessary for the liberation of the Black people in this country.
comments.author: nekocekoBiH

comments.text:
Women today who think they don't need feminism only believe that because 
they have no idea how many women suffered to give them the rights that they 
now take for granted. They can vote, drive a car, have the same jobs as 
men, even ride a bicycle and wear pants, all because of women who dared to 
challenge the male-dominated status quo. Pretending that everything is okay 
and we don't need to fight anymore is exactly the opposite of what those 
women would have believed.﻿

comments.author: Ilyas Miah

comments.text:
+Петър Генов
Uhm, the US has no formal equality before the law for women.

There is no state-sponsored childcare to allow paid work for women.

There are laws that specifically discriminate against women in 85% of all 
counties, mostly anti-abortion laws that establish religious control over 
women's bodies, denying them their human rights in the process.

The US is one of only seven countries on this planet that hasn't ratified 
the UN convention on equality before the law.
The other countries are Iran, Somalia, Sudan, Nauru, Palau and Tonga.

The ERA amendment that should create formal equality before the law is 
being sabotaged and stopped by conservatives for over 20 years because they 
want to discriminate against women.

Creepy groups with 'family' in their name openly campaign that women should 
only be housekeepers and breeders.


....Come again on how there's nothing more to be done for equality in the 
US?
comments.author: Blah b

comments.text:
+ElveeKaye And when was the last time a woman threw herself under a horse, 
because there were not enough non-cis female characters on her favourite TV 
show?

Now, don't get me wrong, there's a huge room for improvement. But not in 
the US. You don't see feminists rallying up for the cause of equality in 
Saudi Arabia or Pakistan—no, they prefer to focus on Instagram, men with 
spreaded legs in the subway, and what they now call "sexism", which 
includes the mere notion of anything sexual by CIS white males.

They don't follow the steps of those suffragettes, they follow the steps of 
the SCUM Manifesto, longing to pull the trigger on anything with a penis, 
just to "prove" their "point". They use Newspeak such as "rape culture", 
and "patriarchy", and "wage gap" to gain credibility and create the 
illusion of a great, looming threat when there is none.

Don't you ever try to measure yourself next to Emily Davison, Elvee Kaye. I 
don't agree with the way she choose to stand up for her rights (threatening 
innocent bystanders), but goddamn it, at the very least she was ready to 
die for them. All you feminists know is to whine, complain, and expect the 
state plus peer pressure to "solve" your illusionary problems and grant you 
with more privileges.

Now fuck off, you neo-Nazi scum.
comments.author: Петър Генов

+Sputterbugz
Uh, do you know the difference between a correlation and a causal link?

Just because women on average earn less per hour doesn't prove their gender 
causes this.

There are very few quality studies that have attempted to calculate 
accurate numbers in order to explain where the difference came from (find 
the cause, the causal link), and their conclusions were:

-Women more often work in parttime, thus damaging their career prospects 
compared to men who work fulltime.
-Maternity leave is both a career damager and a financial risk for 
employers, especially in small businesses that can't support that risk it 
damages your job perspective
-Women are less likely to demand a pay rise than men
-Women more often than men seek employment in sectors that are on average 
poorly paid.
-When renegotiating contracts, women are less agressive in negotiation, 
thus getting less pay rise.

None of the good quality studies (meaning those that didn't just see a 
correlation and stopped thinking there) have actually been able to prove a 
gender wage gap that's caused by gender discrimination.

I get that from what feminists are doing, and which causes they support.

For instance the Dutch 'Equal Treatment Law' (2005) that clearly states in

aimed against the enemy of feminists: men, and white native men in 
particular.

Germany now also has official sexist discriminatory laws, after much 
pressure by feminists. From now on, top executives will no longer be judged 
by their merit, but first by their gender, and they'll be refused a job if 
they're male. A less qualified female on the other hand must be hired:
http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/nov/26/germany-women-quotas-frauenquote-boardrooms

In the US feminists take it a step further. There have been demonstrations 
aimed to pressure universities into committing the offense of vigilantism.
What those feminists demand is that:
When a woman accuses someone of a sex crime (false reports in 22-90% of all 
cases according to studies) the rule of law must be ignored, and the victim 
who's accused must be expelled and barred from school forever, thus 
destroying their life, their career and costing thousands of dollars in 
damages.
That's a frontal assault on order and the rule of law.


Or all-out hatespeech aimed at attacking and persecuting a sexual 
orientation. Feminists engage in homophobic and transphobic hatred. To name 
one example, prominent feminist Sheila Jeffreys in her book Beauty and

comments.author: Valdraya

comments.text:
Davison's purpose in attending the Derby is not clear. She had purchased a 
return rail ticket and a ticket to a suffragette dance later that day, both 
of which are now in the collection of the Women's Library in London, which 
suggests that martyrdom was not her intention. Although it later became 
clear it was the only type of rail ticket available for purchase,[3] it is 
noted that she carefully kept the return half in her purse.[16] Further 
evidence is a postcard she wrote to her sister Laetitia, who lived in 
France and to whom she was very close, which suggests she was going on 
holiday a few days after the Derby to visit her sister and her niece.﻿

comments.author: QuantumLolliepop

comments.text:
+QuantumLolliepop Sorry QuantamLolliepop, but your history teacher is 
completely wrong. The jockey's name was Herbert Jones and he was only 
knocked out and had mild concussion, bruises, abrasions and shock after 
what happened. He committed suicide in 1951, having never really come to 
grips with the loss of his brothers in WW1 and was also quoted as saying 
that he was also "haunted by that poor woman's face".
As for the horse, Anmer, after somersaulting following the collision, he 
got up and kept racing along with the field all the way to the finish, at 
which point he was gathered in. He eventually stood at stud in Canada and 
sired The 1925 Kings Plate winner Fairbank amongst his successful offspring.
These facts are verified by many, many, many sources.

This isn't the only time something like this happened.... a little while 
later at the Ascot carnival, a Trinity College student named James Hewitt, 
ran out onto the course waving a suffragette flag and a revolver, before 
bringing down the easy leader, Tracery, in the Ascot Gold Cup, thankfully 
neither jockey or horse was injured.
comments.author: Danny Warren

trampled by its hoofs as it too fell. Meanwhile, the jockey, Herbert Jones, 
was thrown but had his foot caught in the stirrup. The horse did a 
somersault, got up, and resumed running the race, dragging the unconscious 
Jones before his foot came loose. Bystanders unsuccessfully attempted to 
revive both Davison and Jones, before they were carried off by ambulances﻿

comments.text:
Poor guy....
At the funeral of the leading suffragette Emmeline Pankhurst in 1928, the 
jockey who had ridden Anmer that day, Herbert Jones, laid a wreath "to do 
honour to the memory of Mrs Pankhurst and Miss Emily Davison". Jones had 
suffered a mild concussion in the 1913 collision, but afterwards claimed he 
was "haunted by that poor woman's face".

In 1951, his son found Jones dead in a gas-filled kitchen. The jockey had 
killed himself. ﻿

comments.author: Siobhan Mitchell

comments.text:
For the record, Emily Davison planned to attach a ribbon or scarf to the 
king's horse in the name of publicity. She wasn't attempting suicide or 
harm to the jockey or horse. 
It was an extreme idea, but the entire Suffragette movement had moved on to 
extreme measures. Hunger Strikes, mailing themselves to 10 Downing Street, 
constant arrests - to us now it might seem like an insane level of protest 
and commitment, but these women, who simply wanted the right to vote in 
elections, had already found their cause to be falling on deaf ears.  "What 
are the little ladies on about now?" sort of thing. Letter writing and 
peaceful protest wasn't cutting it any more. 
Was she brave? Yes, she was. If you've ever had even ONE horse galloping at 
you, you know it's a scary thing. To be in the field with all the horses 
was dangerous, and risky, but these were women desperate to be heard. ﻿
comments.author: TheFrogglin

comments.text:
She did not use bombs. The horse and jockey were fine.

She probably did not intend to die from being struck by a horse hoof, I 
don't believe that was her plan.

This was a civil act of disobedence that went wrong, and only she was hurt, 
it was not a terrorist bomb where the bomber intendeds to kill or hurt 
others but not themselves. The two are not equatable. 

It was brave, she risked her own life, and only she paid the consequence. 
This is at a time when many thousands of young men were being asked to lay 
down their lives in the First World War to settle a squabble between kings. 
That, if you are up to it, would be a better contemporary analogy.﻿
comments.author: James Musters

comments.text:
Funny how Americans love their war of independence, based on the belief it 
was about the right to vote on their own affairs, but then leave comments 
on this video suggesting a young women who gave her life for the same 
cause, the right to vote, is a terrorist, or some how soft in the head.﻿
comments.author: James Musters

comments.text:
+xXInfinityDiesXx I'm a female veteran.  I got every single right every man 
I served with, without being obligated to deploy to a war zone, or pass the 
same physical requirements.

A few hundred women dying in war (never having served in a combat role) 
compared to hundreds and hundreds of thousands of men  - ummm.  No.  I 
imagine most of us think of men when it comes to combat death and injury. 
 It's like the 25 women first Responders during 9/11 getting their feelings 
hurt because they weren't given special mention with the over 3,000 male 
responders.

THAT isn't "equality".

As for the rest of your comment, I just think you should forego the Walmart 
brand tin foil and get the good brand - you get better reception through 
your hats I have found.
comments.author: 71SgtMom

comments.text:
+71SgtMom
 I feel that it's important to mention how women *do* fight in wars, they 
just don't get the rights afterwards. Let's look at the French Revolution. 
Women played a major part. They protested and even forced the royal family 
out of Versailles. The women fought when the men couldn't. After it was all 
over, women got absolutely nothing in return. There was a law approved that 
said all *men* could vote, however, it did not include women even though 
they were vital in the struggle. Just because you help fight for a cause 
doesn't mean that you get rewards in the end. Another example can be 
African Americans after WWI. Many fought in the war to prove their loyalty 
to the country and to show they are just as equal as whites. What happened? 
Even more injustice lynchings occurred and organizations like the KKK 
sought to kill them all. White men have always had automatic rights. You 
didn't have to fight for anything. White men are the bad guys. They were 
always the ones oppressing those who were also human. They were the ones 
torturing women and putting other human beings into slavery.
comments.author: xXInfinityDiesXx

comments.text:
+71SgtMom the Soviet Union? The... Soviet Union?!

...THE SOVIET UNION??? Greetings, 1990, from 2015. You should join us.
comments.author: Me Alsome

comments.text:
+71SgtMom I agree that the draft should be abolished or made universal. 
I will also note that all the things you've complained about are due to 
sexist stereotypes. 'Women are more nurturing' leads to women being given 
custody when the father is really the better one at childcare.Men are more 
likely (in the USA) to be expected to suppress their feelings which leads 
to mental health problems, which then leads to being homeless and high 
suicide rates. Outdated ideas about men always wanting sex means women sex 
offenders don't get proper sentencing. As for college graduation rates - is 
this due to failure in the classroom, or do men find other avenues, such as 
trade apprenticeships? As for the Soviet Union - that doesn't exist any 
more. Did you mean Russia?

comments.author: JOhn Anderson

comments.text:
Women have never been assigned combat roles in this country, first off, and 
whether or not you "beleeeve" anyone should be conscripted against their 
will is a moot point - they have NOW started drafting MEN ONLY in the 
Soviet Union to fight in the Ukraine - so don't say there isn't a draft 
anymore.  Men were given the right to vote because they paid for any 
mistakes with their lives - women never have.  If YOU are comfortable with 
the majority voters -women - voting on issues that could end up with YOU 
being drafted, then be my guest.  Women being "in charge" without being 
responsible for outcomes has resulted in the largest MALE prison system the 
world has ever seen, only 37% male college grad rates, 4 x suicide for men 
than women, 89% custody to women, 90% homeless rates for men, boys being 
drugged twice as much as girls in school, and female sex offenders not even 
getting community service - so have at it, stupid.  Let them keep voting 
for YOUR best interests without fear of getting their own hands dirty. Big 
Sister loves you.
comments.author: 71SgtMom

don't think that wearing a uniform is anything like the experiences of 
those who have fought in battles... many of whom have been women.

Are you really suggesting that because an outdated law that treats women as 
'the weaker sex' still exists, women shouldn't be allowed to vote?
comments.author: FerretKibble

comments.text:
Your ignorance is showing - Someone calling herself "SgtMom" just might 
MAYBE have served in the military, ya think???  Hundreds of thousands of 
men dying in combat compared to...none?  I know I was never sent into 
battle.  I signed up and served because I didn't think it was fair MEN have 
to but women don't.  Getting yourself killed doing a stupid stunt does not 
compare to getting drafted and experiencing the horrors of war.  Until 
WOMEN are required to sign up and serve - like MEN are - they should not be 
allowed to vote for those who send MEN into war.  I served - I EARNED the 
right, and I DESERVE it.
